bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Major George Eskridge, June 30, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to his friend and agent in Westmoreland County, Major George Eskridge, June 30, 1729, about his pressing need for cash and urges Eskridge to press the collection of quit rents.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Major George Eskridge, June 30, 1729

opener.dateline:
Corotom[an, Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 30. 1729
Majr. George Eskridge

div1.p:
when you were here I know you intended to
be at our July Court & I hope you will but least you should fail
I can't for bear to put you in mind how poor I am how few bills of
Exchange I have receiv'd this year and how low my stock of Cash is so tht.
I am hardly Able to Pay my debts which I Expect Every day will be
Called for and how little money I receiv'd for my Quit rents this year
not a third of what has been paid me for several years Past

Upon Consideration of these my Uncommon ne:
cessitys I press you strongly to get me all the money you Can I hope
you have begun prosecutions for my fines against those you have
any reason to suspect will not pay without

Mr Downman you told me owns to have
twenty pounds of the money in his hands pray take a right method
to get it of him that I may have it to Answer my Present
Calls And sure of my Other debts will be got this year for me

Mr James Carter tells me he was promised by the
gentlemen of Stafford to pay their rents to the Value of £100
who now shuffle with him and tell him they must Pay Tobo at
last I order him to sue for the money Upon their Assumpsits
thinking my self not Obliged to take Tobo: so late in the year
for their last years rents and I dare say you will be of the same
of Opinion

Colo. Robinson for All his fine promises to you hath
never yet paid his rents to Mr Carter I am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.There is a nineteenth-century copy of this letter in the Minor-Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia.
The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on this draft.

[1] Quit rent was the term used for the payment due from the holder of land to the "lord of the manor," in this case, to the proprietors of the Northern Neck. Carter as the proprietor's agent, collected these payments. No services were required of the landholder as had been true in mediaeval times.

[2] William Downman was a justice of Richmond County from 1718, sheriff in 1722 and 1723, and a tobacco inspector in 1731 and 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . p. 504. and McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]: 12, 34, 238, 286.)
[3] An assumpsit is "an agreement or promise made orally or in writing not under seal; a contract." ("Answers.com." http://www.answers.com/assumpsits&r=67. 7/21/2005)
